DIV1.P: As it was presented by her Majesties Servants at the private House in Drury Lane.
LONDON, Printed by Tho. Cotes, for Andrew Crooke, and William Cooke. and are to be sold at the signe of the Greene Dragon, in Pauls Church-yard. 1640.

LG.L: SInce tis become the Title of our Play,
A woman once in a Coronation may
With pardon, speake the Prologue, give as free
A welcome to the Theater, as he
That with a little beard, a long blacke clok,
With a starch'd face, and supple legge hath spoke
Before the Playes the twelvemonth, let me the▪
Present a welcome to these Gentlemen,
If you be kind, and noble, you will not
Thinke the worse of e for my petticote.
But to the Play, the Poet bad me tell
His feares first in the title, lest it swell
Some thoughts with expectation of a straine,
That but once could be seene in a Kings raigne,
This Coronation, e hopes you may
See often, while the of his Play,
Doth prophsit the Conduites may runne wine,
When the dayes triumph's ended, and divine
Briske Nectar swell his temples to a rage,
With something of more price to invest the stage▪
There rests but to prepare you, that although
It b a Coronation, there doth flow
No undermirth, such as doth lar' the scene
For course delight, the language here is cleare.
And confident our Poet bad me say,
Heele bate you but the folly of a Play.
For which although dull soules his pen dispise,
Who thinkes it yet too earely to be wise.
The nobler will thanke his muse, at least
Excuse him, cause his thought aym'd at the best,
But we conclude not, it dost rest in you.
To cnsure Poet, Play, and Prologue too.
But what have I omitted? is there not
A blush upon my cheekes that I forgt
The Ladies, and a Female Prologue too?
Your pardon noble Gentlewomen, you
Were first within my thoughts, I know you sit
As free, and high Commissioners of wit,
Have cleare, and active soules, nay though the men
Were lost in your eyes, they'l be found agen,
You are the bright intelligences move,
And make a harmony this sphere of Love,
Be you propitious then, our Poet sayes,
Our wreath from you, is worth their grove of Bayes:

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: MAke way for my Lord Protector.

SP.SPEAKER: Cas.
SP.P: I like your diligent waiting, where's Li∣simachus?

SP.SPEAKER: Cas.
SP.L: The Queene lookes pleasant
This morning, does she not?

SP.SPEAKER: Lis.
SP.L: I ever found
Her gracious smiles on me.

SP.SPEAKER: Cas.
SP.L: She does consult
Her safety in't, for I must tell thee boy,
But in the assurance of her love to thee,
I should advance thy hopes another way,
And use the power I have in Epire, to
Settle our owne, and uncontrouled greatnesse;
But since she carries her selfe so fairely,
I am content to expect, and by her marriage
Secure thy fortune, that's all my ambition
Now, be still carefull in thy applications
To her, I must attend other affaires,
Returne, and use what art thou canst to lay
More charmes of love upon her.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisi.
SP.L: I presume
Shee alwayes speakes the language of her heart,
And I can be ambitious for no more
Happinesse on earth then she encourages
Me to expect.

SP.SPEAKER: Cas.
SP.L: It was an act becomming
The wisedome of her Father to engage
A tye betweene our families, and she
Hath playd her best discretion to allow it;
But we lose time in conference, waite on her,
And be what thou wert borne for, King of Epire, Exit.
I must away.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisi.
SP.L: Successe ever attend you.
Is not the Queene yet comming forth?

SP.SPEAKER: Lisa.
SP.L: Your servant,
You may command our duties,
This is the Court starre Philocles.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: The starre that we must saile by.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisa.
SP.L: All must borrow
A light from him, the young Queene directs all
Her favours that way.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Hees a noble Gentleman
And worthy of his expectations:
Too good to be the son of such a Father.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisa.
SP.P: Peace, remember he is Lord Protector.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: We have more need of Heavens protection
I'th meane time, I wonder the old King
Did in his life designe him for the office.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisa.
SP.L: He might suspect his faith, I have heard when
The King who was no Epirote advanc'd
His claime, Cassander, our Protector now,
Young then, oppos'd him toughly with his faction,
But forc'd to yeeld had faire conditions,
And was declar'd by the whole state next heire
If the King wanted issue; our hopes only
Thriv'd in this daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Whom but for her smiles
And hope of marriage with Lasimachus,
His Father by some cunning had remov'd
Ere this.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisa.
SP.L: Take heed, the Arras may have eares
I should not weepe much if his grace would hence
Remove to Heaven.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: I prethee what should he do there?

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: And the sky too, ere I get one staire higher
While hee in place.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: How lookes the day upon us? where's the Queene?

SP.SPEAKER: Lisa.
SP.P: None but the yong Lord Lisimachus.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Tis no treason
If a man wish himselfe a Courtier
Of such a possibility: he has
The mounting fate.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: I would his Father were
Mounted toth' gallowes.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: He has a path faire enough,
If he survive by title of his Father.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisa.
SP.P: The Queene will hasten his ascent.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Thou wod'st become rarely the peticote,
What wod'st thou doe?

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Why, I wod marry
My Gentleman usher, and trust all the strength
And burden of my state upon his legges,
Rather then be call'd wife by any sonne
Of such a Father.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisa.
SP.L: Come lets leave this subject,
We may finde more secure discourse; when saw
You young Arcadius, Lord Macarius Nephew?

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Theres a sparke, a youth moulded for a favorite,
The Queene might doe him honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Favorite, tis too cheape a name, there were a match
Now for her Virgin blood.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisa.
SP.L: Must every man
That has a hansom face or legge feed such
Ambition: I confesse I honour him,
He has a nimble soule, and gives great hope
To be no woman-hater, dances hansomely,
Can court a Lady powerfully, but more goes
Toth' making of a Prince? hees here
Ands Vncle.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: Save you Gentlemen, who can direct me
To finde my Lord Protector?

SP.SPEAKER: Lisa.
SP.L: He was here
Within this halfe houre, young Limachus
His sonne is with the Queene.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: There let him complement,
I have other businesse, ha? Arcadius!

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Observ'd you with what eyes Arcadius
And he saluted, their two families
Will hardly reconcile.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.L: Seleucus carries
Himselfe too roughly, with what pride and scorne
He past by em.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisa.
SP.L: The tother with lesse shew
Of anger carries pride enough in's soule,
I wish em all at peace, Macarius lookes
Are without civill warre, a good old man,
The old King lov'd him well, Seleucus Father
Was as deare to him, and maintain'd the character
Of an honest Lord through Epire: that two men
So lov'd of others, should be so unwell-come
To one another.

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.P: The Queene was not wont to send for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mac.
SP.L: The reason's to her selfe,
It will become your duty to attend her.

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.L: Save you Gentlemen, what novelty
Does the Court breath to day?

SP.SPEAKER: Lisa.
SP.L: None sir, the newes
That tooke the last impression is, that you
Purpose to leave the Kingdome, and those men,
That honour you, take no delight to heare it.

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.L: I have ambition to see the difference
Of Courts, and this may spare; the delights
At home doe surfet, and the mistresse whom
We all doe serve is fixt upon one object,
Her beames are too much pointed, but no Country
Shall make me lose your memories.

SP.SPEAKER: Mac.
SP.L: Your Lordship honord me,
I have no blessing in his absence.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisi.
SP.P: Tis done like a pious Vncle.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: We must not
Give any licence.

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.L: If your Majesty
Would please.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: We are not pleasd, it had become your duty,
To have first acquainted us, ere you declar'd
Your resolution publicke, is our Court
Not worth your stay?

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: We shall finde
Employment at home for you, doe not lose us.

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.L: Madam I then write my selfe blest on earth
When I may doe you service.

SP.SPEAKER: Mac.
SP.L: Madam you have blest me,
Nothing but your command could interpose to
Stay him.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: You must not leave us.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisa.
SP.L: Nothing but Lisimachus? has she not
Taine a philter?

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: Nay pray be cover'd, Ceremony from you.
Must be excus'd,

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: Not your love?
I know you would not have me looke upon
Your person as a Courtier, not as favorite,
That title were too narrow to expresse
How we esteeme you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisi.
SP.L: The least of all
These names from you Madam, is grace ēnough.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.P: Yet here you wod not rest.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisi.
SP.L: Not if you please?
To say there is a happinesse beyond,
And teach my ambition how to make it mine,
Although the honours you already have
Let fall upon your servant, exceed all
My merit; I have a heart is studious
To reach it with desert, and make if possible
Your favours mine by justice, with your pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: We are confident this needs no pardon sir,
But a reward to cherish your opinion,
And that you may keepe warme your passion,
Know we resolve for marriage, and if
I had another gift, beside my selfe,
Greater, in that you should discerne, how much
My heart is fixt.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.P: But I cannot resolve when this shall be,

SP.SPEAKER: Lisi.
SP.L: How Madam? doe not make me dreame of Heaven
And wake me into misery, if your purpose
Be, to immortalize your humble servant,
Your power on earth's divine, Princes are here
The Coppies of eternity, and create
When they but will our happinesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: I shall
Beleeve you mocke me in this argument,
I have no power.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.P: I must obey, your Fathers my Protector.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: When I am absolute, Lisimachus,
Our power and titles meete, before, we are but
A shadow, and to give you that were nothing,

SP.SPEAKER: Lisi.
SP.L: Excellent Queene,
My love tooke no originall from state,
Or the desire of other greatnesse,
Above what my birth may challenge modestly,
I love your vertues; mercenary soules
Are taken with advancement, yo've an Empire
Within you, better then the worlds, to that
Lookes my ambition.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: Tother is not sit
To be despisd, Cosmography allowe
Epire a place ith' mappe, and know till I
Possesse what I was borne to, and alone
Doe graspe the Kingdomes Scepter, I account
My selfe divided, he that marries me
Shall take an absolute Queene to his warme bosome,
My temples yet are naked, untill then
Our loves can be but complements, and wishes,
Yet very hearty ones.

SP.SPEAKER: Cas.
SP.P: Madam, a Gentleman has an humble sute,

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: Tis in your power to grant, you are Protector,
I am not yet a Queene.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: Madam to reconcile two families
That may unite, both counsells and their blood
To serve your Crowne.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: Macarius, and Eubulus
That by are inveterate malice to each other.
It grew, as I have heard▪ upon the question
Which some of either family had made,
Which of their Fathers was the best commander:
If we beleeve our stories, they have both
Deserved well of our state, and yet this quarrell
Has cost too many lives, a severe faction.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: But Ile propound a way to plant a quiet
And peace in both our houses, which are torne
With their dissentions, and lose th glory
Of their great names, my blood speakes my relation
To Eubulus, and I wish my veines were emptyed
To appease their warre.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: Thou hast a noble soule,
This is a charity above thy youth,
And it flowes bravely from thee, name the way.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: In such a desperate cause, a little streame
Of blood might purge the foulenesse of their hearts
If youle prevent a deluge.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: Let but your Majesty consent, that two
May with their personall valour undertake
The honour of their family, and determine
Their diffrence.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: This rather will inlarge
Their hate, and be a meanes to call more blood
Into the streame.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: Not if both families
Agree, and sweare—

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.P: And who shall be the Champions.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: I beg the honour, for Eubulus cause
To be ingag'd, if any for Macarius,
Worthy to wager heart with mine, accept it,
I am confident, Arcadius
For honour would direct to his sword,
Will not deny, to stake against my life
His owne, if you vouchsafe us priviledge.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: You are thē expectation and toppē boughs
Of both your houses, it would seeme injustice,
To allow a civill warre to cut you off,
And your selves the instruments, besides
You appeare a souldier, Arcadius
Hath no acquaintance yet with rugged warre,
More fit to drill a Lady then expose
His body to such dangers: a small wound
Ith' head may spoyle the method of his haire▪
Whose curiosity exacts more time
Than his devotion, and who knowes but he
May lose his riban by it in his locke,
Deare as his Saint, with whom he would exchange
His head, for her gay colours; then his band
May be disorderd, and transform'd from Lace
To Cutworke, his rich cloathes be discomplexioned
With blood, beside the infashionable slashes,
And at the next festivall take physicke,
Or put on blake, and mourne for his slaine breeches:
His hands cas'd up in gloves all night, and sweate
Pomatum, the next day may be endanger'd
To blisters with a sword, how can he stand
Vpon his guard, who hath fiders in his head,
To which, his feet must ever be a dancing.
Beside a falfy may spoyle his cringe,
Or making of a legge, in which conssts
Much of his Court perfection.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: Is this Character
Bestow'd on him?

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: It something may concerne the Gentleman,
Whom if you please to challenge
To dance, play on the Lute, or sing.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: He shall not want those will maintaine him
For any summe.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: You are my Soveraigne,
I dare not thinke, yet I must speake somewhat,
I shall burst else, I have no skill in jigges,
Nor .

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: Nor was I borne a Minstrell, and in this you have
So infinitely disgraced Arcadius,
But that I have heard another Character,
And with your royall licence doe beleeve it,
I should not thinke him worth my killing.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: Does she not jeerē mee;
I shall talke treason presently, I finde it
At my tongues end already, this is an
Affront, Ile leave her.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.P: Come backe, doe you know Arcadius?

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: I ha changd but little breath with him, our persons
Admit no familiarity, we were
Borne to live both at distance, yet I ha seēne him
Fight, and fight bravely.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: When the spirit of Wine
Made his braine valliant he fought bravely.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: Although he be my enemy, should any
Of the gay flyes that buzze about the Court,
Sit to catch trouts ith▪ summer, tell me so,
I durst in any presence but your owne.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.P: Tell him he were not honest.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: I see Seleucus thou art esolute,
And I but wrong'd Arcadius, your first
Request is granted, you shall fight, and he
That conquers be rewarded to confirme
First place and honour to his family:
Is it not this you plead for?

SP.SPEAKER: Cas.
SP.L: I wish thy sword may open
His wanton veines, Macarius is too popular,
And has taught him to inuate.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: It shall
But haste the confirmation of our loves,
And ripen the delights of marriage, Seleucus.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisi.
SP.L: As I guest,
It cannot be too soone.

SP.SPEAKER: Cas.
SP.L: To morrow then we crowne her, and invest
My sonne with Majesty, tis to my wishes,
Beget a race of Princes my Lisimachus.

SP.SPEAKER: Cas.
SP.L: Thy brow was made
To weare a golden circle, 'me transported,
Thou shalt rule her, and I will governe thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisi.
SP.L: Although you be my Father, that will not
Concerne my obedience, as I take it. Enter Philocles, Lisander, and Antigonus.
Gentlemen,
Prepare your selves for a solemnity
Will turne the Kingdome into triumph, Epire
Looke fresh to morrow, become your duties
In all your glory to attend the Queene
At her Coronation, she is pleased to make
The next day happy in our Callender,
My Office doth expire, and my old blood
Renewes with thought on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisa.
SP.L: And he so jofull to resigne his regency,
There's some tricke in't, I doe not like these hasty
Proceedings, and whirles of state, they have commonly
As strange and violent effect; well, heaven▪ save the Queen.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Heaven save the Queene say I, and send her a sprightly
Bed-fellow for the Protector, let him pray for
Himselfe, he is like to have no benefit of my devotion.

SP.SPEAKER: Cas,
SP.L: But this doth quicken my old heart Lisimachus,
There is not any step into her throne,
But is the same degree of thy owne state;
Come Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisi.
SP.L: What heretofore could happen to mankinde
Was with much paine to clime to heaven, but in
Sophias marryage of all Queenes the best,
Heaven will come downe to earth▪ to make me blest.

DIV2.HEAD: Actus Secundus.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: To travell,
I know you see me, but to take your leave,
But I must never yeeld to such an absence.

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.L: I prethee leave thy feares, I am commanded
Toth' contrary, I wonot leave thee now.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: I am very glad, for trust me, I could thinke
Of thy departure with no comfort, thou
Art all the joy I have, halfe of my soule;
But I must thanke the Queene now for thy company,
I prethee what could make thee so desirous
To be abroad?

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.L: Onely to get an appetite
To thee Polidora.

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.P: Nay, prethee doe not so mistake thy servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.P: Perhaps you surfeit with my love.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Although I have no beauty to comparē
With the best faces, I have a heart above
All competition.

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.L: Thou art jealous now;
Come, let me take the kisse I gave thee last,
I am so confident of thee, no lippe
Has ravisht it from thine; I prethee come
To Court.

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.P: There is the throne for beauty.

SP.SPEAKER: Arc,
SP.L: Theres none will hurt,
Or dare but thinke an ill to Polidora,
The greatest will be proud to honour thēē.
Thy luster wants the admiration here:
There thou wot shine indeed, and strike a reverence
Into the gazer.

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.L: No praise of thee can be thought so, thy vērtue
Will deserve all, I must confesse, we Courtiers
Doe oftentimes commend to shew our art,
There is necessity sometimes to say,
This Madam breaths Arabian Gummes,
Amber and Cassia; though while we are praysing,
We wish we had no nostriles to take in
The offensive steame of her corrupted lungs.
Nay, some will sweare they love their Mistresse,
Would hazard lives and fortunes, to preserve
One of her haires brighter then Berinices;
Or young Apollos, and yet after this,
A favour from another toy would tempt him
To laugh, while the Officious hangman whips
Her head off.

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.L: I am none of these,
Nay, there are women Polidora too
That can doe pretty well at flatteries;
Make men beleeve they dote, will languish for em,
Can kisse a Iewell out of one, and dally
A carcanet of Diamonds from another,
Weepe intoth' bosome of a third, and makē
Him drop as many pearles; they count it nothing
To talke a reasonable heire within ten dayes
Out of his whole estate, and make him mad
He has no more wealth to consume.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Youle teach me
To thinke I may be flattered in your promises,
Since you live where this art is most profest.

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.L: I dare not be so wicked Polidora,
The Infant errors of the Court I may
Be guilty off, but never to abuse
So rare a goodnesse, nor indeed did ever
Converse with any of those shames of Court,
To practise for base ends; be confident
My hēart is full of thine, and I so deepely
Carry the figure of my Polidora,
It is not in the power of time or distance▪
To cancell it, by all thats blest I love thee:
Love thee above all women, dare invoke
A curse when I forsake thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Let it be some
Gentle one.

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.L: Teach me an oath I prethee,
One strong enough to binde, if thou dost finde
Any suspition of my faith, or else
Direct me in some horrid imprecation
When I forsake thee, for the love of other
Woman, may heaven reward my apostacy
To blast my greatest happinesse on earth,
And make all joyes abortive.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Revoke these hasty syllables, they carry
To great a penalty for breach of Love
To me, I am not worth thy suffering,
You doe not know what beauty may invite
Your change, what happinesse may tempt your eye
And heart together.

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.L: Should all the graces of your sex conspire
In one, and she should court me, with a dower
Able to buy a Kingdome when I give
My heart from Polidora.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: I suspect not,
And to requite thy constancy I sweare.

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.L: Twere sinne to let thee waste thy breath
I have assurance of thy noble thoughts.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: My Lord, your Vncle hath beene every where
Ith Court inquiring for you, his lookes speake
Some earnest cause.

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.L: I am more acquainted with
Thy vertue then to imagine thou wilt not
Excuse me now, one kisse dismisses him
Whose heart shall waite on Polidora, prethee
Let me not wish for thy returne too often,
My Father.

SP.SPEAKER: Nes.
SP.L: I met Arcadius in strange haste, he told me
He had beene with thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Some affaire too soone
Ravish'd him hence, his Vncle sent for him
You came now from Court: how lookes the Queenē
This golden morning?

SP.SPEAKER: Nes.
SP.L: Like a bride, her soule
Is all on mirth, her eyes have quickning fires,
Able to strike a spring into the earth
In Winter.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Then Lisimachus can havē
No frost in's blood, that lives so neere her beames.

SP.SPEAKER: Nes.
SP.L: His politicke Father, the Protector smiles too,
Resolve to see the Cerimony of the Queene
Twill be a day of state,

SP.SPEAKER: Nes.
SP.L: How▪ not well? retire then, I must returne
My attendance is expected, Polidora,
Be carefull of thy health.

SP.SPEAKER: Mac.
SP.L: Deare Nephew, if thou respect thy safety,
My honour, or my age, remove thy selfe,
Thy lifes in danger.

SP.SPEAKER: Mac.
SP.L: Take horse, and instantly forsake the City,
Or else within some unsuspected dwelling,
Obscure thy selfe, stay not to know the reason.

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.L: Sir, I beseech your pardon, which ith▪ number
Of my offences unto any, should
Provoke this dishonorable flight?

SP.SPEAKER: Mac.
SP.L: I would when I petition'd for thy stay,
I had pleaded for thy banishment, thou knowst not
What threatens thee:

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.L: I would desire to know it,
I am in no conspiracy of treason,
Have ravisht no mans Mistresse, not so much
As given the lye to any, what should meane
Your strange and violent feares, I will not stirre
Vntill you make me sensible I have lost
My innocence.

SP.SPEAKER: Mac.
SP.L: I must not live to see
Thy body full of wounds, it were lesse sinnē
To rippe thy Fathers marble, and fetch from
The reverend vault his ashes, and disperse them
By some rude windes where none should ever find
The sacred dust, it was his legacy,
The breath he mingled with his prayers to Heaven
I should preserve Arcadius, whose fate
He prophesied in death, would need protection,
Thou wot disturbe his ghost, and call it to
Affight my dreames, if thou refuse to obey me.

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.L: You more inflame me to inquire the cause
Of your dstraction, and youle arme me better
Then any coward flight by acquainting me
Whose malice aimes to kill me, good sir tell me,

SP.SPEAKER: Mac.
SP.P: Then prayers and teares assist me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mac.
SP.L: Thou art a rash young man, witnesse the spirit
Of him that trusted me so much, I bleed,
Till I prevent this mischiefe.

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.L: I know your faces, but
Am not secure, I would not be betray'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisa.
SP.P: You wrong our hearts, who truely honour you.

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.P: They say I must be kild.

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.P: I know not, nor wod I part with life so tamely.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: We dare ingage ours in your quarrell, hide
Your sword, it may beget suspition,
It's enough to question you.

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.L: I am confident,
Pray pardon me, come I despise all danger:
Yet a deare friend of mine, my Vncle told me
He would not see my body full of wounds.

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.L: Yes, my honest Vncle,
If my unlucky starres have pointed me
So dire a fate.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: There is some strange mistake in'.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant
SP.L: Arcadius, the Queene would speake with you,
You must make haste.

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.L: Though to my death, I fly
Vpon her summons, I give up my breath
Then willingly, if she command it from me.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: This does a little trouble me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisa.
SP.L: I know not
What to imagine, something is the ground
Of this perplexity, but I hope there is not
Any such danger as he apprehends.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Queene, Lisimachus, Macarius, Eubulus, Seleucus, Arcadius, Ladies and attendants, Gent.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: We have already granted to Seleucus
And they shall try their valour if Arcadius
Have spirit in him to accept the challenge,
Our royall word is past.

SP.SPEAKER: Eub.
SP.L: Madam my sonnē knew not what he asked,
And you were cruell to consent so soone.

SP.SPEAKER: Mac.
SP.L: Wherein have I offended, to be rob'd
At once of all the wealth I have, Arcadius
Is part of me.

SP.SPEAKER: Eub.
SP.L: Seleucus life and mine
Are twisted on one thred, both stand or fall
Together, hath the service for my Country
Deserved but this reward, to be sent weeping
To my eternall home? Wast not enough
When I was young, to lose my blood in warres,
But the poore remnant that is scarcely warme
And faintly creeping through my withered veines
Must be let out to make you sport.

SP.SPEAKER: Mac.
SP.L: How can
We that shall this morne seē the sacred oyle
Fall on your virgin tresses▪ hope for any
Protection hereafter, when this day
You sacrifice the blood of them that pray for you.
Arcadius I prethee speake thy selfe,
It is for thee I plead.

SP.SPEAKER: Eub.
SP.L: Seleucus, kneele
And say thou haste repented thy rash suite;
If ere I see thee fight, I be thus wounded,
How will the least drop forc'd from thy veines,
Afflict my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Mac.
SP.L: Why, that's good;
Arcadius speake to her; heare him Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.L: If you call backe this honour you have done me
I shall repent I live, doe not perswade me
Seleucus thou art a noble enemy,
And I will love thy soule though I dispaire
Our bodies friendly conversation:
I would we were to tugge upon some cliffe,
Or like two prodigies ith ayre, our conflict
Might generally be gaz'd at, and our blood
Appease our grandsires ashes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: Madam, my father sayes I have offended,
If so, I begge your pardon, but beseech you
For your owne glory call not backe your word.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: No more, we have resolv'd,
And since their courage is so nobly flamed,
This morning weele behold the Champions
Within the list, be not affraid, their strife
Will stretch so farre as death, so soone as we
Are Crown'd prepare your selves, Selucus.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: I have receiv'd another life in this high favour,
And may lose what nature gave me.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: Arcadius to encourage thy young vallour,
We give thee our Fathers sword.
Command it from our Armory; Lisimachus,
To our Coronation.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: Ile forfeit
My hēad for a rebellion then suffer it.

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.L: I am circled with confusions Ile doē somewhat
My braines and friends assist me.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: But doe you thinke they le fight indeed?

SP.SPEAKER: Lisa.
SP.L: Perhaps
Her Majesty will see about or two.
And yet tis wondrous strange, such spectacles
Are rare ith' Court, and they were to skirmish naked
Before her, then there might be some excuse.
There is some gimcrackes in't, the Queene is wise
Above her yeares.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisa.
SP.L: I cannot blame him, but my Lord
Returne, they are both troubled, las good men,
But our duties are expected, we forget.

SP.SPEAKER: Eub.
SP.L: I must resolve, and yet things are not ripe,
My braines upon the torture.

SP.SPEAKER: Mac.
SP.L: This may quit
The hazard of his person, whose least drop
Of blood is worth more then our families.
My Lord Eubulus, I have thought a way
To stay the young mens desperate proceedings,
It is our cause they fight, let us beseech
The Queene, to grant us two the priviledge
Of duell▪ rather then expose their lives
To eithers fury; it were pitty they
Should runne upon so blacke a destiny,
We are both old, and may be spar'd, a paire
Of fruitlesse trees, mossie and withered trunckes,
That fill up too much roome.

SP.SPEAKER: Eub.
SP.L: Most willingly,
And I will praise her charity to allow it;
I have not yet forgot to use a sword,
Lets lose no time, by this act, she will licence
Our soules to leave our bodies but a day,
Perhaps an houre the sooner; they may live
To doe her better service, and be friends
When we are dead, and yet I have no hope
This will be granted, curse upon our faction.

SP.SPEAKER: Eub.
SP.L: There's something oth' suddaine strucke upon
My imagination, that may secure us.

SP.SPEAKER: Mac.
SP.L: Name it, if no dishonour waite upon't
To preserve them, Ile accept any danger.

SP.SPEAKER: Eub.
SP.L: There is no other way, and yet my heart
Would be excus▪d but tis to save his life.

SP.SPEAKER: Eub.
SP.L: In your eare I shall,
It shanot make a noyse if you refuse it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mac.
SP.L: Hum? though it stirre my blood, Ile meet Arcadius,
If this preserve thee not, I must unseale
Another mystery.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Queene, Lisimachus, Cassander, Charilla, Lisander, Philocles, Antigonus.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: We owe to all your loves and will deserve
At least by our indeavours that none may
This day repent their prayers, my Lord Protector.

SP.SPEAKER: Cas.
SP.L: Madam I have no
Such title now, and am blest to lose
That name so happily, I was but trusted
With a glorious burden.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: You have prov'd
Your selfe our faithfull counsellor, and must still
Protect our growing state, a Kingdomes Scepter
Weighs downe a womans arme, this crowne sits heavy
Vpon my brow already, and we know
There's something more then mettle in this wreath,
Of shining glory, but your faith, and counsell,
That are familiar with mysteries,
And depths of state▪ have power to make us fit
For such a bearing, in which both you shall
Doe loyall service, and reward your duties.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: But yet my Lords and Gentlemen let nonē
Mistake me, that because I urge your wisdomes,
I shall grow carelesse, and impose on you
The managing of this great Province, no,
We will be active too, and as we are
In dignity above your persons, so,
The greatest portion of the difficulties
We call to us, you in your severall places
Releeving us with your experience,
Observing in your best directions
All modesty, and distance, for although
We are but young, no action shall forfeit
Our royall priviledge, or encourage any
Too unreverent boldnesse, as it will become
Our honour to consult, ēre we determine
Of the most necessary things of state,
So we are sensible of a checke,
But in a brow, that saucily controules
Our action, presuming on our yeares
As few, or frailty of our sex, that head
Is not secure that dares our power or justice.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: She has a brave spirit, looke how the Protector
Growes pale already.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: But I speake to you
Are perfect in obedience, and may sparē
This theame, yet 'twas no immateriall
Part of our character, since I desire
All should take notice, I have studied
The knowledge of my selfe, by which I shall
Better distinguish of your worth and persons
In your relations to us.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisa.
SP.L: This language
Is but a threatning to some body

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: But we misse some, that use not to absent
Their duties from us, where's Macarius?

SP.SPEAKER: Cas.
SP.L: Retir'd to grieve, your Majesty hath given▪
Consent Arcadius should enter List
To day with young Seleucus.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: We purpose Enter Gentleman▪
They shall proceed, whats he?

SP.SPEAKER: Phil,
SP.L: A Gentleman belonging to Seleucus, that givēs notice
He is prepar'd, and waites your royall pleasure,

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: He was composd for action, give notice
To Arcadius, and admit the challenger,
Let other Princes boast their gaudy tilting,
And mockery of battles, but our triumph
Is celebrated with true noble vallour. Enter Selucus, Arcadius at severall doores, their pages before them bearing their Targets.
Two young men spirited enough to have
Two Kingdomes staked upon their swords, Lisimachus
Doe not they excellently become their armes,
Twere pitty but they should doe something more
Then wave their plumes. a shout within.
What noyse is that?

SP.SPEAKER: Mac.
SP.L: The peoples joy to know us reconcild,
Is added to the Iubile of the day,
We have no more a faction but one heart,
Peace flow in every bosome.

SP.SPEAKER: Eub.
SP.L: Throw away
These instruments of death, and like two friends
Imbrace by our example.

SP.SPEAKER: Mac.
SP.L: By our duties to your selfe deare Madam
Command them not advance, our houses from
This minute are incorporated, happy day
Our eyes at which before revenge looke forth,
May cleare suspition, oh my Arcadius!

SP.SPEAKER: Eub.
SP.L: We have found a neerer way to friendship Madam,
Then by exposing them to fight for us.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: If this be faithfull our desires are blest,
We had no thought to waste, but reconcile
Your blood this was and we did prophesie
This happy chance, spring into eithers bosome,
Arcadius and Seleucus, what can now
Be added to this dayes felicity;
Yes, there is something, is there not my Lord?
While we are Virgin Queene.

SP.SPEAKER: Ca.
SP.L: Ha, that string
Doth promise musicke.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: I am yet my Lords
Your single joy, and when I looke upon,
What I have tooke, to manage the great care
Of this most flowrishing Kingdome, I incline
To thinke, I shall doe justice to my selfe,
If I chose one, whose strength and vertue may
Assist my undertaking, thinke you Lords,
A husband would not helpe?

SP.SPEAKER: Lisa.
SP.L: No question Madam,
And he that you purpose to make so blest
Must needs be worthy of our humblest duty,
It is the generall vote.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: We will not then
Trouble Embassadors to treat with any
Princes abroad, within our owne dominion,
Fruitefull in honour, we shall make our choyce;
And that we may not keepe you over long
Jn the imagination, from this circle, we
Have purpose to elect one, whom I shall
Salute a King and Husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Que,
SP.L: Nor shall we in this action be accused
Of rashnesse, since the man we shall declare
Deserving our affection, hath beene earely
In our opinion, which had reason first
To guide it, and his knowne nobility
Long marryed to our thoughts, will justifie
Our faire election.

SP.SPEAKER: Cas.
SP.P: Direct our duties Madam to pray for him.

SP.SPEAKER: Que
SP.L: Arcadius you see from whence we come,
Pray lead us backe, you may ascend.

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.L: Madam be charitabe to your humblest creature,
Doe not eward the heart, that falls in duty
Beneath your feete, with making me the burden
Of the Court mirth, a mockery for Pages,
Twere treason in me but to thinke you meane thus.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: Arcadius you must refuse my love,
Or shame this Kingdome.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: Is the winde in that corner?

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: He kisses her, now by this day I am glad on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Ant.
SP.P: Let him fret his heart strings.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.P: Is the day cloudy on the suddaine?

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.L: Gentlemen
It was not my ambition, I durst never
Aspire so high in thought, but since her Majesty
Hath pleasd to call me to this honour, I
Will study to be worthy of her grace,
By whom I live.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: The Church to morrow shall
Confirme our marriage, noble Lisimachus
Weele finde out other wayes to recompence
Your love to us, set forward, come Arcadius.

SP.SPEAKER: Mac.
SP.P: It must be so, and yet let me consider,

SP.SPEAKER: Cas.
SP.L: He insults already, policy assist me.
To breake his necke.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisi.
SP.L: Who would trust woman?
Lost in a paire of minutes, lost, how bright
A morning rose, but now, and now tis night?

DIV2.HEAD: Actus Tertius.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Oh where shall Virgins looke for faith hereafter?
If he prove false, after so many vowes?
And yet if I consider, he was tempted
Above the strength of a young Lover, two
Such glorious courting his acceptance, were
Able to make disloyalty no sinne,
At least not seeme a fault, a Lady first,
Whose very lookes would thaw a man more fro
Then the Alps, quicken a soule more dead then Winter.
Adde to her beauty and perfection,
That she's a Queene, and brings with her a Kingdome
Able to make a great mind forfeit heaven.
What could the frailety of Arcadius
Suggest to unspirit him so much, as not
To fly to her embraces, you were present
When she declar'd her selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Tell me,
Did not he make a pause, when the faire Queene
A full temptation stood him?

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: Very little
My judgement could distinguish, she did no sooner
Propound, but he accepted.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: That was ill,
He might with honour stand one or two minutes,
Me thinkes it should have startled him a little,
To have rememberd me, I have deserv'd
At least a cold thought, well pray give it him.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Not so,
But take a time when his joy swels him most,
When his delights are high and ravishing,
When you perceive his soule dance in his eyes,
When she that must be his, hath drest her beanty
With all her pride, and sends a thousand Cupids
To call him to the tasting of her lippe;
Then give him this, and tell him while I live,
Ile pray for him.

SP.SPEAKER: Cas.
SP.P: There is no way but death.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisi.
SP.L: That's blacke and horrid,
Consider sir it was her sinne, not his;
I cannot accuse him, what man could carry
A heart so frozen, not to melt at such
A glorious flame? who could not fly to such
A happinesse?

SP.SPEAKER: Cas.
SP.L: Have you ambition
To be a tame foole fee so vast an injury
And not revenge it? me not suspect
Thy Mother for this sufferance, my Sonne.

SP.SPEAKER: Cas.
SP.L: Heare a patient gull,
A property, thou hast no blood of mine,
If this affront provoke thee not, how canst
Be charitable to thy selfe, and let him live
To glory in thy shame? Nor is he innocent;
He had before crept slily into her bosome
And practised thy dishonour.

SP.SPEAKER: Cas.
SP.L: How else could she be guilty
Of such contempt of thee? and in the eye
Of all the Kingdome, they conspir'd this staine,
When they had cunning meetings, shall thy love
And blooming hopes be scattered thus, and Lisimachus
Stand idle gazer?

SP.SPEAKER: Lisi.
SP.L: What sir will his death
Advantage us, if she be false to me?
So irreligious, and to touch her person—
Pause we may be observed.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisa.
SP.L: 'Tis the Protector
And his sonne.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Alas poore Gentleman, I pitty
His neglect, but am not sorry for his Father.

SP.SPEAKER: Cas.
SP.L: I am yours Gentlemen,
And should be happy to deserve your loves.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisa.
SP.L: In't sir, to inlarge your sufferings, J have
A heart doth wish
The Queene had knowne better to reward
Your love and merit.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisa▪
SP.L: If you would expresse
Your love to me; pray doe not mention it,
I must obey my fate.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: She will be marryed
To tother Gentleman for certaine then?

SP.SPEAKER: Cas.
SP.P: I hope youle wish em joy.

SP.SPEAKER: Cas.
SP.L: We are growne
Ridiculous, the pastime of the Court:
Here comes another.

SP.SPEAKER: Cas.
SP.P: Like a neglected servaut of his Mistresse.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.P: I would aske him a question.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: Whether the Queene
As tis reported, lov'd him, he can tell
Whether she promist what they talke of, marriage,

SP.SPEAKER: Cas.
SP.P: I can resolve you that sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.P: Then shees a woman, and your sonne;

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: Not worthy his blood, and expectation,
If he be calme.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: The destinies, that's all your pardon sir,
I am Seleucus still, a poore shaddow
Oth' world, a walking picture, it concernes
Not me, I am forgotten by my starres.

SP.SPEAKER: Cas.
SP.L: The Queene with more discretion might ha chosen
Thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: Me? I cannot dance, and frike with due activity,
My body is led, I have too much phleame, what should
I doe with a Kingdome? no Arcadius
Becomes the cushion, and can please, yet setting
Aside the tricke that Ladies of blood looke at,
Another man might mae a shift to weare
Rich cloathes, sit in the chare of state, and nod,
Dare venture on discourse, that does not trench
On complement, and thinke the study of armes
And arts, more commendable in a Gentleman
Than any galliard.

SP.SPEAKER: Cas.
SP.L: And you were reconcil'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: We? yes, oh yes,
But tis not manners now to say we are friends,
At our equality there had beene reason,
But now, subjection is the word.

SP.SPEAKER: Cas.
SP.L: They are not
Yet marryed.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: make no oath upont,
My Lord Lisimachus,
A word. youe not be angry if I love you,
May not a batchellor be made a cuckold?

SP.SPEAKER: Cas.
SP.L: Lisimachus, this
Is worth our embrace, hees spiritted,
And may be usefull.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: Harke you, can you tell
Where's the best Dancing-master? and you meane
To rise at Court, practise to caper, farewell
The noble science, that makes worke for cutlers,
It will be out of fashion to weare swords,
Masques, and devices welcome, I salute you.
Is it not pitty any division
Should be heard ou of Musicke? Oh twill be
An excellent age of crotchets; and of Canters.
Buy Captaines that like fooles will spend your blood
Out of your Country, you will be of lesse
Vse then your feathers, if you returne unman'd
You shall be beaten soone to a new march,
When you shall thinke it a discretion
To sell your glorious buffes to buy fine pumps,
And pantables, this is I hope no treason.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Areadius leading the Queene, Charia, , Lisander, Philocks, Polidor a, servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisi.
SP.L: Yes sir,
And shew a patience above her injury.

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.L: This honour is too much, Madam assume
Your place, and let Arcadius waite still:
Tis happinesse enough to be your servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: This is not musicke
Sprightly enough, it feeds the soule with melancholy.
How sayes Arcadius?

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.L: Give me leave to thinke
There is no harmony but in your voyce,
And not an accent of your heavenly tongue,
But strikes me into rapture, I incline
To thinke the tale of Orphe no fable,
Tis possible he might inchant the Rockes,
And charme the Forrest, soften hell, hell it selfe
With his commanding Lute, it is no miracle
To what you worke, whose very breath conveyes
The hearer into heaven, how at your lips,
Day winds gather perfumes, proudly glide away,
To disperse sweetnesse round about the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.L: Not if I should say
Nature had plac'd you here the creatures wonder,
And her owne spring, from which all excellence
On earths deriv'd, and copyed forth, and when
The character of faire, and good in others
Is quite worne out, and lost, looking on you
It is supplide, and you alone made mortall
To feed and keepe alive all beauty.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.P: Ha, ha, can you indure it Gentlemen?

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: Nay aske him what he meanes, mine is a downe
Right laugh.

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.L: At such bright eies the stars do light themselves,
At such a forehead Swans renew their white,
From such a lip the morning gathers blushes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: The morning is more modest then thy prayses,
What a thing does he make her?

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.L: And when you fly to heaven & leave this world
No longer maintenance of goodnesse from you,
Then Poetry shall lose all use with us,
And be no more, since nothing in your absence
Is left, that can be worthy of a Verse.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.P: Have you ambition to be punishd sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: I need not, twas punishment
Enough to heare him make an Idoll of you, he left
Out the commendation of your patience, I was a little
Mov'd in my nature to heare his codomontados, and
Make a monster of his Mistresse, which I pittyed first,
But seeing him proceed, I guest he brought you
Mirth with his inventions, and so made bold to laugh at it.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: You are sawcy,
Weele place you where you shannot be so merry,
Take him away.

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.P: Let me plead for his pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: I wod not owe my life so poorely, beg thy owne
When you are King you cannot bribe your destiny.

SP.SPEAKER: Eub.
SP.L: Good Madam heare me, I feare he is distracted,
Brave boy, thou should'st be master of a soule
Like his: thy honours more concernd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: 'Tis charity,
A way wo' mee, 'boy Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.L: These and a thousand more affronts I must
Expect: your favours draw them all upon me;
In my first state I had no enemies,
I was secure while I did grow beneath
This expectation, humble valleyes thrive with
Their bosomes full of flowers, when the hils melt
With lightning, and rough anger of the clouds,
Let me retire.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: And can Arcadius
A such a breath be moved, I had opinion
Your courage durst have stood a tempest for
Our love, can you for this incline to leave
What other Princes should in vaine have sued for?
How many Lovers are in Epire now
Would throw themselves on danger, not expect
Oe enemy, but empty their owne veines,
And thinke the losse of all their blood rewarded,
To have one smile of us when they are dying?
And shall this murmure shake you?

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.L: Not deare Madam,
My life is such a poore despised thing,
In value your least graces, that
To lose it were to make my selfe a victory,
It is not for my selfe I feare: the envy
Of others cannot fasten wound in me
Greater, then that your goodnesse should be check'd
So daringly.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: Let not those thoughts afflict thee
While we have power to correct the offences
Arcadius be mine, this shall confirme it.

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.L: I shall forget
And lose my way to heaven, that touch had beene
Enough to have restor'd me, and infused
A spirit of a more celestiall nature,
After the tedious absence of my soule,
Oh blesse me not too much, one smile a day
Would stretch my life to mortality,
Poets that wrap divinity in tales,
Looke here, and give your coppyes forth of angels,
What blessing can remaine?

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.L: Place then some horrors in the way
For me, not you to passe, the journeys end
Holds out such glories to me, I should thinke
Hell but a poore degree of suffering for it,
Whats that some petition, a Letter to me. You had a Polidora, ha, thats all.
Ith' minute when my vessels new lanch'd forth,
With all my pride and silken winges about me
I strike upon a Rocke: what power can save me?
You had a Polidora; theres a name
Kil'd with griefe I can so soone forget her

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: She did impose on me this service sir,
And while she lives she sayes sheele pray for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Aarc.
SP.L: Shee lives
Thats well, and yet twere better, for my fame,
And honour she were dead, what fate hath plac'd me
Vpon this fearefull precipice?

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.L: I must resolve, my faith is violated
Already, yet poore loving Polidora
Will pray for me, she sayes, to thinke she can
Render me hated to my selfe, and every
Thought's a tormentor, let me then be just.

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.L: That voyce prevailes agen, oh Poledora,
Thou must forgive Arcadius, I dare not
Turne rebell to a Princesse, I shall love
Thy vertue, but a Kingdome has a charme
To excuse our frailty, dearest Madam.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Macarius, and a Bishop, Casander.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: My Lord Macarius we did want your person,
There's something in our joyes wherein you share.

SP.SPEAKER: Mac.
SP.P: This you intend your highnesse wedding day.

SP.SPEAKER: Mac.
SP.L: Save you labour
I have brought a Priest to meet you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mac.
SP.P: To tell you that you must not marry.

SP.SPEAKER: Bish.
SP.L: Madam tis a rule
First made in heaven, and I muh needs declare
You and Arcadius must tie no knot
Of man and wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: Ioy has transported him,
Or age has made him dote, Macarius
Provoke us not too much, you will presume
Above our mercy.

SP.SPEAKER: Mac.
SP.L: Ile discharge my duty,
Could your frowne strike me dead, my Lord you know
Whose character this is.

SP.SPEAKER: Cas.
SP.L: It is Thedosius.
Your graces Father.

SP.SPEAKER: Mac.
SP.P: Feare not, Ile crosse this match.

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.L: Vncle dee know what you doe, or what we are
Going to finish, you will not breake the necke of my glorious
Fortune, now my footes ith' stirrups and mounting,
Throw me over the saddle, I hope youle let one
Be a King, Madam 'tis as you say,
My Vncle is something craz'd, there is a worme
In's braine, but I beseech you pardon him, he is
Not the first of your counsell, that has talk'd
Idly, dee heare my Lord Bishop, I hope
You have more religion then to joyne with him
To undoe me.

SP.SPEAKER: Bis.
SP.L: Not I sir, but I am commanded by oath,
And conscience to speake truth.

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.L: If your truth should doe me any harme, I shall never
Be in charity with a Croziers staffe, looke too't.

SP.SPEAKER: Mac.
SP.L: Deliver to me an Infant with this writing,
To which this reverend Father is a witnesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisa.
SP.P: This he whom we so long thought dead, a childe.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: But what should make my father to trust him
To your concealement? give abroad his death, and bury
An empty coffin?

SP.SPEAKER: Mac.
SP.L: A jealousie he had
Vpon Cassander, whose ambitious braine
He fear'd would make no conscience to depose
His sonne, to make Lisimachus King of Epire.

SP.SPEAKER: Que.
SP.L: He made no scruple to expose me then
To any danger?

SP.SPEAKER: Mac.
SP.L: He secur'd you Madam
By an earely engagement of your affection
To Lisimachus, exempt this testimony,
Had he beene Arcadius, and my Nephew
I needed not obtrude him on the state,
Your Love and marriage had made him King
Without my trouble, and sav'd that ambition
There was necessity to open now
His birth, and title.

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.P: What riddles are these, whom do they talk of?

SP.SPEAKER: Omn.
SP.L: Congratulate your returne to life, and honor,
And as becomes us, with one voyce salute you
Demetrius King of Epire.

SP.SPEAKER: Mac.
SP.L: I am no Vncle, sir, this is your sister,
I should have suffered incest to have kept you
Longer ith' darke, love, and be happy both,
My trust is now discharg'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.L: But doe not mooke me Gentlemen,
May I be bold upon your words to say
I am Prince Thedosius sonne.

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.L: Youle justifie it?
Sister I am very glad to see you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sop.
SP.L: I am to finde a brother, and refigne my glory,
My triumph is my shame.

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.L: Gentlemen I owe
Vnto your loves, as large acknowledgement
As to my birth for this greath onour, and
My study shall be equall to be thought
Worthy of both.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisi.
SP.P: There will be the lesse charge for my monument.

SP.SPEAKER: Cas.
SP.P: This must not be, fit fast young King.

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.L: My sister should have beene my Bride, that name
me in minde of Polidora, ha?
Lisander, Philocles, Gentlemen,
If you will have me thinke your hearts allow me
Thedosius sonne, oh quickely snatch some wings,
Expresse it in your haste to Polidora,
Tell her what title is new dropt from Heaven
To make her rich; onely created for me,
Give her the ceremony of my Queene,
With all the state that may become our Bride
Attend her to this throne; are you not there?
Yet stay, tis too much pride to send for her,
Weele goe our selfe, no honour is enough
For Polidora, to redeeme our fault
Salute her gently from me, and upon
Your knee, present her with this Diademe,
Tis our first gift, tell her Demetrius followes
To be her guest, and give himselfe a servant
To her chaste bosome, bid her stretch her heart
To meet me, I am lost in joy and wonder.

DIV2.HEAD: Actus Quartus.

SP.SPEAKER: Cas.
SP.P: VVHeres the Captaine of the Castle?

SP.SPEAKER: Cas.
SP.P: Give him knowledge we expect him.

SP.SPEAKER: Cas.
SP.L: He is my creature, feare not,
And shall runne any curse that we propod.

SP.SPEAKER: Eub.
SP.L: My Lord, I like the substance of your plot,
Tis promising, but matters of this consequence
Are not so easily perfect, and it does
Concerne our heads to build upon secure
Principles, though Seleus, I confesse,
Carry a high, and daring spirit in him,
Tis hard to thrust upon the state new setled
Any impostor, and we know not yet
Whether heele undertake to play the Prince;
Or if he should accept it, with what cunning
He can behave himselfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Cas.
SP.L: My Lord, affaires
Of such a glorious nature, are halfe finish'd
When they beginne with confidence.

SP.SPEAKER: Fub.
SP.L: Admit
He want no art, nor courage, it must rest
Vpon the people to receive his title,
And with what danger their uncertaine breath
May flatter ours, Demetrius scarcely warme
In the Kings seate, I may suspect.

SP.SPEAKER: Cas.
SP.L: That reason
Makes for our part, for if it be so probable,
That young Demetrius should be living, why
May not we worke them to beleeve Leoatus
The eldest sonne was by some tricke preserv'd
And now would clame his owne: there were two sons,
Who in their Fathers life we supposed dead,
May not we finde a circumstance to make
This seeme as cleare as t'other, let the vulgar
Be once possest, weele carry Epire from▪
Demetrius, and the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Eub.
SP.L: I could be pleasd
To see my sonne a King. Enter Poleanus.
The Captaiues here.

SP.SPEAKER: Cas.
SP.L: We come to visit your late prisoner▪
I will not doubt, but you intreate him fairely
He will deserve I for himselfe, and you
Be fortunate in any occasion
To have exprest your service.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Sir, the knowledge
Of my honourable Lord his Father, will
Instruct me to behave my selfe with all
Respects becomming me, to such a sonne.

SP.SPEAKER: Cas.
SP.L: These things will least
Obleige you, but how beares he his restraint?

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.P: As one whose soule's above it.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: With contempt rather of the great command
Which made him prisoner, he will talke sometimes
So strangely to himselfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: Why was I borne to be a subject? 'tis
Soone answer'd, sure my Father was no Prince,
Thats all, the same ingredience use to make
A man, as active, though not royall blood
Went to my composition, and I
Was gotten with as good a will perhaps,
And my birth cost my mother as much sorrow,
As I had beene borne an Emperour.

SP.SPEAKER: Cas.
SP.L: While I looke
Vpon him, something in his face presents
A King indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Eub.
SP.L: He does resemble much
Thedosius too.

SP.SPEAKER: Cas.
SP.L: Whose sonne we would pretend him,
This will advance our plot,

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: Tis but a name,
And meere opinion, that preferres one man
Above another, Ile imagine thn
I am a P rince, or some brave thing on earth,
And see what followes, but it must not be
My fingle voyce will carry it, the name
Of King must be attended with a troope
Of acclamations, on whose ayrie Wings
He mounts, and once exalted threatens Heaven,
And all the starres: how to acquire this noyse,
And be the thing I talke of, men have rise
From a more cheape nobility to Empires,
From darke originalls, and sordid blood,
Nay some that had no fathers, sons of the earth,
And flying people, have aspir'd to Kingdomes,
Made nations tremble, any have practis'd frownes
To awe the world, their memory is glorious,
And I would hugge them in their shades, but whats
All this to me; that am I know not what,
And lesse in expectation?

SP.SPEAKER: Cas.
SP.P: Will you assist, and runne a fate with us.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.P: Command my life, I owe it to your favour.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: Arcadius was once as farre from being
As I, and had we not so cunningly
Beene reconcil'd, or one, or both had gone
To seeke our fortunes in another world;
What's the devie now? If my death be next,
The summons shall not make me once looke pale.

SP.SPEAKER: Cas.
SP.L: Chide your too vaine suspitions, we bring
A life, and liberty, with what else can make
Thy ambiion happie, th'ast a glorious flame
We come to advance it.

SP.SPEAKER: Cas.
SP.L: Have but a will,
And be what thy owne thoughts dare prompt thee to,
A King.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: You doe not moke me Gentlemen,
You are my father sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Eub.
SP.L: This minute hall
Declare it my Selucus, our hearts swel'd
With joy, with duty rather, oh my boy▪

SP.SPEAKER: Cas.
SP.L: Selucus, tay thou art too incredulous,
Let not our faith, and studdy to exalt thee,
Be so rewarded.

SP.SPEAKER: Eub.
SP.L: I pronounce thee King
Vnlesse thy spirit be turn'd coward, and
Thou faint to accept it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: Although the Queen since she sent me hither
Were gone to Heaven I know not how
That title could devolve to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Cas.
SP.L: We have
No Queene, since he that should have marryed her,
Is prov'd her youngest brother, and now King
In his owne title.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: Thanke you Gentlemen,
There's hope for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Cas.
SP.L: Why, you dare fight with▪him
And need be, for the Kingdome.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: With Arcadius,
If youle make stakes, my life against his crowne,
Ile fight with him, and you, and your fine sonne,
And all the Courtiers one after another.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.P: I am of your Lordships minde, so fare you well

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: What? that you have betraide me,
Doe, tell your King, my life is growne a burden,
And Ile confesse, and make your soules looke pale,
To see how nimble mine shall leape this battlement
Of flesh, and dying, laugh at your poore malice.

SP.SPEAKER: Ones▪
SP.P: No more, long▪ live Leonatus King of Epire.

SP.SPEAKER: Cas.
SP.L: Be bold and be a King, our braines have beene
Working to raise you to this height, here are
None but friends, dare you but call your selfe
Leonatus, and but justifie with considence
What weele proclaime you, if we doe not bring
The Crowne to your head, we will forfeit ours.

SP.SPEAKER: Eub.
SP.L: The state is in distraction, Arcadiu
Is prov'd a King, there was an elder brother,
If you dare but pronounce, you are the same,
Forget you are my sonne.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: These are no trifles, sir, all is plotted
To assure your greatnesse, if you will be wise,
And take the faire occasion that's presented.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: Arcadius, you say, is lawfull King,
And now to depose him, you would make me
An elder brother, is't not so?

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.P: Nay, right or wrong, if this be your true meaning.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: Ile venture mine, but with your pardon,
Whose braine was this? from whom tooke this plot life?

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: And you are of his minde? and you? and thinke
This may be done?

SP.SPEAKER: Eub.
SP.L: The destinies shall not crosse us, if you have
Spirit to undertake it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: Vndertake it?
I am not us'd to complement, Ile owe
My life to you, my fortunes to your Lordship,
Compose me as you please, and when y'ave made
Me what you promise, you shall both divide
Me equally, one word my Lord, I had rather
Live in the prison still, then be a propency
To advance his politicke ends.

SP.SPEAKER: Cas.
SP.L: So, so, I see Demetrius heeles already
Trip'd up, and Ile dispatch him out oth' way,
Which gone, I can depose this at my leasure
Being an Impostor, then my sonne stands faire,
And may peece with the Princesse, we lose time,
What thinke you, if we first surprize the Court,
While you command the Castle, we shall curbe
All opposition.

SP.SPEAKER: Eub.
SP.L: Let's proclaime him first.
I have some faction, the people love me,
They gain'd to us, weele all upon the Court.

SP.SPEAKER: Cas.
SP.P: Vnlesse Demetrius yeeld himselfe he bleeds.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.P: Who dares call treason sinne, when it sueceeds?

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.L: Madam, you are too passionate, and lose
The greatnesse of your soule, with the expence
Of too much griefe, sor that which providence
Hath eas'd you of, the burden of a state
Above your tender bearing.

SP.SPEAKER: Sop.
SP.L: Thar't a foole,
And canst not reach the spirit of a Lady,
Borne great as I was, and made onely lesse
By a too cruell destiny, above
Our tender bearing? what goes richer to
The composition of man, then ours?
Our soule as free, and spacious, our heart's
As great, our will as large, each thought as active,
And in this onely man more proud then wee,
That would have us lesse capable of Empire,
But search the stories, and the name of Queene
Shines bright with glory, and some precedents
Above mans imitation.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.L: I grant it
For the honour of our sex, nor have you, Madam,
By any weakenesse forfeited command,
He that succeeds, in justice, was before you,
And you have gain'd more in a royall brother
Then you could lose by your refigne of Epire.

SP.SPEAKER: Sop.
SP.L: This I allow Charilla, I ha done;
Tis not the thought I am deposd afflicts me,
At the same time I feele a joy to know
My Brother living: no, there is another
Wound in me above cure.

SP.SPEAKER: Sop.
SP.P: Canst finde me out a Surgeon for that?

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.L: Oh doe not injure
Your owne cleare innocence.

SP.SPEAKER: Sop.
SP.L: Doe not flatter me,
I have beene guilty of an act, will make
All love in women questioned, is not that
A blot upon a Virgins name? my birth
Cannot extenuate my shame, I am
Become the staine of Epire.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.L: Tis but
Your owne opinon, Madam, which presents
Something o fright your selfe, which cannot
Be in the same shape so horrid to our sense.

SP.SPEAKER: Sop.
SP.L: Thou wod'st but canst not appeare ignorant,
Did not the Court, nay, the whole Kingdome, take
Notice I lov'd Lisimachus?

SP.SPEAKER: Sop.
SP.L: No. I was false
Though counseld by my Father to affect him,
I had my politicke ends upon Cassander,
To be absolute Queene, flattering his son with hopes
Of love and marriage, when that very day
I blush to thinke I wrong'd Lisimachus,
That noble Gentleman, but heaven punish'd me;
For though to know Demetrius was a blessing,
Yet who will not impute it my dishonour.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.L: Madam, you yet may recompence Lisimachus,
If you affect him now, you were not false
To him whom then you lov'd not, if you can
Finde any gentle passion in your soule
To entertaine his thought, no doubt his heart,
Though sad, retaines a noble will to meet it,
His love was firme to you, and cannot be
Vnrooted with one storme.

SP.SPEAKER: Sop.
SP.L: He will not sure
Trust any language from her tongue that mock'd him,
Although my soule doth weepe for't, and is punish'd
To love him above the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.L: Hees here
As fate would have him reconcild, be free,
And speake your thoughts.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisi.
SP.L: If Madam I appeare
Too bold, your charity will signe my pardon:
I heard you were not well, which made me haste
To pay the duty of an humble visite.

SP.SPEAKER: Sop.
SP.P: You doe not mocke me sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisi.
SP.L: I am confident
You thinke me not so lost to manners, in
The knowledge of your person, to bring with me
Such rudenesse, I have nothing to present,
But a heart full of wishes for your health,
And what else may be added to your happinesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Sop.
SP.P: I thought you had beene sensible.

SP.SPEAKER: Sop.
SP.L: A man of understanding, can you spend
One prayer for me, remembring the dishonour
I have done Lisimachus?

SP.SPEAKER: Lisi.
SP.L: Nothing can deface that part of my
Religion in me, not to pray for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sop.
SP.L: It is not then impossible you may
Forgive me too, indeed I have a soule
Is full of penitence, and something else,
If blushing would allow to give't a name.

SP.SPEAKER: Sop.
SP.L: Love, a love that should redeeme
My past offence, and make me white againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisi.
SP.L: I hope no sadnesse can possesse your thoughts
For me, I am not worthy of this sorrow,
But if you meane it any satisfaction
For what your will hath made me suffer, 'tis
But a strange overflow of charity,
To keepe me still alive, be your selfe Madam,
And let no cause of mine, be guilty of
This rape upon your eyes, my name's not worth
The least of all your teares.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisi.
SP.L: Although I may
Suspect a womans smile hereafter, yet
I would beleeve their wet eyes, and if this
Be what you promise, for my sake, I have
But one reply.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisi.
SP.L: I have now
Another Mistresse.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisi.
SP.L: To whom I have made
Since your revolt from me, a new chaste vow,
Which not the second malice of my fate
Shall violate, and she deserves it Madam,
Even for that wherein you are excellent,
Beauty, in which she shines equall to you
Her vertue, if he but maintaine what now
She is Mistresse of, beyond all competition,
So rich it cannot know to be improv'd,
At least in my esteeme, I may offend,
But truth shall justifie, I have not latterd her,
I beg your pardon, and to leave my duty
Vpon your hand, all that is good flow in you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sop.
SP.L: Did he not say Charilla, that he had
Another Mistresse?

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.L: Such a sound me thought
Came from him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sop.
SP.L: Let's remove, here's too much ayre,
The sad note multiplies.

SP.SPEAKER: Cha.
SP.L: Take courage Madam,
And my advice, he has another Mistresse,
If he have twenty, be you wise, and crosse him
With entertaining twice as many servants,
And when he sees your humour heele returne,
And sue for any Livery, grieve for this,
It must be she, 'tis Polidora has
Taken his heart, she live my rivall,
How does the thought inflame me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sop.
SP.L: And yet she does but justly, and he too;
I would have rob'd her of Areadius heart,
And they will both have this revenge on me,
But something will rebell.

SP.SPEAKER: De.
SP.L: The house is desolate, none comes forth to meete us,
Shees slow to entertaine us, Philocles,
I prethee tell me, did she weare no cloud
Vpon her brow, wast freely that she said
We should be welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: To my apprehension,
Yet tis my wonder she appeares not.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisa.
SP.L: She nor any other,
Sure there's some conceite
To excuse it.

SP.SPEAKER: Dem.
SP.P: Stay, who's this? observe what followes?

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: Fortune? some maske to entertaine you sir.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Fortune crown'd, attended with Youth, Health, and Pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.L: Not yet? what silence doth inhabite here?
No preparation to bid Fortune welcome!
Fortune the genious of the world, have we
Descended from our pride, and state to come
So farre attended with our darlings, Youth
Pleasure, and Health, to be neglected thus?
Sure this is not the place? call hither Fame.

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.L: Know,
Who dwels here.

SP.SPEAKER: Fa.
SP.L: Once more I report great Queene,
This is the house of Love.

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.L: It cannot be,
This place has too much shade, and lookes as if
It had beene quite forgotten of the Spring,
And sunne beames Love, affect society
And heate, here all is cold as the haires of Winter,
No harmony to catch the busie eare
Of passengers, no object of delight,
To take the wandring eyes, no song, no grone
Of Lovers, no complaint of Willow garlands,
Love has a Beacon upon his palace top
Of flaming hearts, to call the weary pilgrime
To rest, and dwell with him, I see no fire
To threaten, or to warme, can Love dwell here?

SP.SPEAKER: Fa.
SP.L: If there be noble love upon the world,
Trust Fame, and finde it here.

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.L: Make good your boast
and bring him to us.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisa.
SP.L: I told you sir we should have some device, Enter Love.
There's Cupid now, that little Gentleman,
Has troubled every masque at Court this seven yeare.

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.L: Welcome to Love, how much you honor me!
It had become me, that upon your summons
I should have waited upon mighty Fortune,
But since you have vouchsafed to visite me;
All the delights Love can invent, shall flow
To entertaine you, Musicke through the ayre
Shoote your inticing harmony.

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.P: We came to dance and revell with you

SP.SPEAKER: Lov.
SP.L: I am poore
In my ambition, and want thought to reach
How much you honor Love.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon.
SP.L: What intrusion's this?
Whom doe you seeke here.

SP.SPEAKER: Lov.
SP.P: Fortune is come to visit us.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon.
SP.L: And has
Corrupted Love, is this thy faith to her,
On whom we both waite, to betray her thus
To Fortunes triumph, take her giddy wheele,
And be no more companion to honour
I blush to know thee, whole beleeve there can
Be truth in Love hereafter?

SP.SPEAKER: Lov.
SP.L: I have found
My eyes, and see my shame, and with it, this
Proud sorceresse, from whom, and all her charmes,
I flye agen to Honour, be my guard,
Without thee I am lost and cannot boast,
The merit of a name.

SP.SPEAKER: For.
SP.L: Dispis'd? I shall
Remember this affront.

SP.SPEAKER: Dem.
SP.L: What morral's this? Exeunt. Enter Honour with the Crowne upon a mourning Cushion.
What melancholly object strikes a suddaine
Chillnesse through all my veines, and turnes me Ice?
It is the same I sent, the very same,
As the first pledge of her insuing greatnesse,
Why in this mourning livery, if she live
To whom I sent it? ha, what shape of sorrow? Enter Polidora in mourning.
It is not Polidora, she was faire
Enough, and wanted not the setting off
With such a blacke, if thou beest Polidora,
Why mournes my love? it neither does become
Thy fortune nor my joyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: But it becomes
My griefes, this habit fits a funerall,
And it were sinne, my Lord, not to lament
A frie ndnew dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Dem.
SP.L: And I yet living? can
A sorrow enter but upon thy garment,
Or discomplexion thy attire, whilst I
Enjoy a life for thee? who can deserve
Weigh'd with thy living comforts, but a peice
Of all this Ceremony? give him a name

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: A Gentleman that lov'd me dearely once,
And does compell these poore, and fruitlesse drops,
Which willingly would fall upon his hearse,
To imbalme him twice.

SP.SPEAKER: Dem.
SP.P: And are you sure hees dead?

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: As sure as you're living sir, and yet
I did not close his eyes, but he is dead,
And I shall never see the same Arcadius,
He was a man so rich in all that's good,
At least J thought him so, so perfect in
The rules of honour, whom alone to imitate
Were glory in a Prince, Nature her selfe
Till his creation wrought imperfectly,
As she had made but tryall of the rest,
To mould him excellent.

SP.SPEAKER: Dem.
SP.L: And is he dead?
Come, shame him not with praises, recollect
Thy scattered hopes, and let me tell my best,
And dearest olidora, that he lives,
Still lives to honour thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Dem.
SP.L: Looke here.
Am not I worth your knowledge?

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: And my duty,
You are Demetrius King of Epire, sir.
I could not easily mistake him so,
To whom I gave my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Dem.
SP.L: Mine is not chang'd,
But still hath fed upon thy memory,
These honours, and additions of state
Are lent me for thy sake, be not so strange,
Let me not lose my entertainement now
I am improv'd, ad raisd unto the height,
Beneath which, I did blush to aske thy love.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Give me your pardon sir, Arcadius,
At our last meeting without argument
To move him more then his affection to me,
Vow'd he did love me; love me bove all women,
And to confirme his heart was truely mine,
He wish'd, I tremble to remember it,
When he forsooke his Polidora's love,
That Heaven might kill his happinesse on earth:
Was not this nobly said, did not this promise
A truth to shame the Turtles?

SP.SPEAKER: Dem.
SP.L: And his heart
Is still the same, and I thy coustant Lover.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Give me your leave I pray, I would not say
Arcadus was perjur'd, but the same day
Forgetting all his promises, and oathes,
While yet they hung upon his lips, for sooke me,
Dee not remember this too, gave his faith
From me, transported with the noyse of greatnesse,
And would be marryed to a Kingdome.

SP.SPEAKER: Dem.
SP.L: But heaven permitted not I should dispose
What was ordain'd for thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: It was not vertue
In him, for sure he found no checke, no sting
In his owne bosome, but gave freely all
The reines to blind ambition.

SP.SPEAKER: Dem.
SP.L: I am wounded,
The thought of thee ith' throng of all my yes,
Like poyson powr'd in Nectar, turnes me franticke,
Deare, if Arcadius have made a fault,
Let not Demetrius be punishd for't,
He pleads that ever will be constant to thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Shall I beleeve mans flatteries agen,
Lose my sweete rest, and peace of thought agen,
Be drawne by you, from the streight paths of vertue
Into the maze of Love.

SP.SPEAKER: Dem.
SP.L: I see compassion in thy eye, that chides me
If I have either soule, but what's containd
Within these words▪ or if one sillable
Of their full force, e not made good by me,
May all relenting thoughts in you take end,
And thy disdaine be doubled, from thy pardon,
Ile count my Coronation, and that houre
Fix with a rubricke in my Calender,
As an auspicious time to entertaine
Affaires of weight with Princes, thinke who now
Intreates thy mercy, come thou sha't be kinde,
And divide titles with me

SP.SPEAKER: Pol,
SP.L: Heare me sir,
I lov'd you once for vertue, and havē not
A thought so much unguarded as to be wonne
From my truth, and innocence with any
Motives of state to affect you,
Your bright temptation mournes while it staies here
Nor can the triumph of glory, which made you
Forget me, so court my opinion backe,
Were you no King, I should be sooner drawne
Againe to love you, but tis now too late,
A low obedience shall become me best▪
May all the joyes I want
Still waite on you, if time hereafter tell you
That sorrow for your fault hath strucke me dead,
May one soft teare drop from your eye, in ty
Bedew my hearse, and I shall sleepe secuely
I have but one word more for goodnesse sake,
For your owne honour sir correct your passion
To her you shall love next, and I forgive you.

SP.SPEAKER: Dem.
SP.L: Her heart is frozen up, nor can warme prayers
Thaw it to any softnesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: You give your passion too much leave to triumph.
Seeke in another what she denies.

SP.SPEAKER: Mac.
SP.L: Where's the King? oh sir, you are undone,
A dangerous treason is a foote.

SP.SPEAKER: Mac.
SP.L: Cassander, and Eubulus havē proclaim'd
Another King, whom they pretend to be
Leonatus your elder brother, he that was,
But this morning prisoner in the Castle.

SP.SPEAKER: Mac.
SP.L: The easie Epirotes
Gather in multitudes to advance his title,
They have seased upon the Court, secure your person
Whilst we raise power to curbe this insurrection.

SP.SPEAKER: Dem.
SP.L: We will not arme one man,
Speake it agen, have I a brother living?
And must be no King.

SP.SPEAKER: Dem.
SP.L: This newes doth speake me happy, it exalts
My heart, and makes me capable of more
Then twenty Kingdomes.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Will you not sir, stand
Vpon your guard?

SP.SPEAKER: Dem.
SP.L: Ile stand upon my honour,
Mercy releives me.

SP.SPEAKER: Dem.
SP.L: The worlds too poore to bribe me, leave
Me all, lest you extenuate my fame, and I
Be thought to have redeem'd it by your counsell,
You shall not share one scruple in the honour;
Titles may set a glosse upon our name,
But vertue onely is the soule of Fame.

DIV2.HEAD: Actus Quintus.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisa.
SP.L: Tis a Kingdome
Easily purchasd, who will trust the faith
Of multitudes?

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: It was his fault, that would
So tamely give hi title to their mercy,
Thē nēw King has possession.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisa.
SP.L: And is like
To keep't, we are alone, what doft thinke of
This innovation? ift not a fine ligge?
A precious cunning in the late Protector
To shuffle a new Prince into the state.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: I know not how they have shuffled, but my head on't
A false card is turn'd up trump, but fates looke too't.

SP.SPEAKER: Eub.
SP.P: Does he not carry it bravely.

SP.SPEAKER: Cas.
SP.L: Excellently.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi. Lis.
SP.L: Your Lordships servants,
Are we not bound to heaven, for multiplying
These blessings on the Kingdome.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Heaven alone
Workes miracles my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lisa.
SP.L: I thinke your Lordship
Had as little hope once, to see these Princes
Revive.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Here we must place our thankes,
Next providence, for preserving
So deere a pledge.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: It is our pleasure
The number of our guard be doubled, give
A Largesse to the Soldiers; but dismisse not
The troopes till we command.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: It will not please us otherwise, my Lord,
We have tride your faith,

SP.SPEAKER: Eub.
SP.P: Does he not speakē with confidence?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: My Lords, and Gentlemen, to whose faith we must
Owe next to heaven our fortune, and our safety,
After a tedious eclipse, the day
Is bright, and we invested in those honours,
Our blood, and birth did challenge.

SP.SPEAKER: Cas.
SP.L: May no time
Be registred in our annalls, that shall mention
One that had life to oppose your sacred person,

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Let them whose titles forg'd and flaw'd suspect
Their states security, our right to Epire,
Heaven is oblig'd to prosper, teason has
No face so blacke to fright it, all my cares
Levell to this, that I may worthily
Manage the province, and advance the honour
Of our deere Country, and be confident,
If an expence of blood, may give addition
Of any happinesse to you, I shall
Offer my heart the sacrifice, and rejoe
To make my selfe a ghost, to have inscrib'd
Vpon my marble, but whose cause I dyed for.

SP.SPEAKER: Cas.
SP.L: Excellent Prince,
In whom we see the Coppy of his Father
None but the sonne of Theodosius,
Could have spoke thus.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: You are pleasd to interpret well,
Yet give me leave to say in my owne justice,
I have but exprest the promptnesse of my soule
To serve you all, but tis not empty wishes
Can satisfie our mighty charge, a weight
Would make an Atlas double, a Kings name
Doth sound harmoniously to men at distance,
And those who cannot penetrate beyond
The barke, and outskinne of a common wealth,
Or state, have eyes but ravish'd with the Ceremony
That must attend a Prince, and understand not
What cares allay the glories of a Crowne,
But good Kings finde and feele the contrary,
You have tride, my Lord▪ the burden, and can tell
It would require a Pilote of more yeares
To steere this Kingdome, now impos'd on me,
By justice of my birth.

SP.SPEAKER: Cas.
SP.L: I wish not life,
But to partake those happy dayes, which must
Succeed these faire proceedings, we are blest,
But sir be sparing to your selfe, we shall
Hazard our joyes in you too soone, the burden
Of statē affaires impose upon your counsell.
Tis fitter that we waste our lives then you,
Call age too soone upon you with the trouble,
And cares that threaten such an undertaking,
Preserve your youth.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
